docs.title: Information technology - City data model - Part 2: City level concepts
docs.text:
The Information technology - City data model - Part 2: City level concepts ontology consists of the following:

  • 5087-2
  • Alert Pattern
  • Building Pattern
  • Bylaw Pattern
  • City Pattern
  • City Resident Pattern
  • City Service Pattern
  • Code Pattern
  • Contact Pattern
  • Contract Pattern
  • Core
  • Household Pattern
  • Infrastructure Pattern
  • Land Use Pattern
  • Organization Pattern
  • Person Pattern
  • Transport Infrastructure Pattern

This ontology specifies the city-level concepts of the city data model.

This pattern imports the following patterns:

  • Building Pattern
  • Bylaw Pattern
  • Contract Pattern
  • Household Pattern
  • Transport Infrastructure Pattern
  • sosa
  • ssn

This pattern does not contain any classes.

The formal definition of this pattern is available in OWL Syntax.

docs.title: Building Pattern
docs.text:
This ontology specifies the city-level concepts for the building pattern of the city data model. A Building is a structure with some location in the urban system. The location of the Building in space may change due to construction, but the Parcel/Lot of land it is located on cannot. There may be many different types (subclasses) of buildings, such as House, Apartment Building, Office Building, and so on.

This pattern imports the following patterns:

  • Infrastructure Pattern

This pattern consists of the following classes:

  • Area Ratio
  • Building
  • Building Thing
  • Building Unit
  • Building Use
  • Construction Status
  • Facility
  • Year

The formal definition of this pattern is available in OWL Syntax.

docs.title: City Pattern
docs.text:
This ontology specifies the city-level concepts for the city pattern of the city data model. The City pattern captures basic information about the geospatial aspects of the city. In particular it represents the different ways in which the city is administratively divided.

This pattern imports the following patterns:

  • Land Use Pattern

This pattern consists of the following classes:

  • City
  • City Administrative Area
  • City Pattern Thing
  • Jurisdictional Area (CityPattern)

The formal definition of this pattern is available in OWL Syntax.

docs.title: CityPatternThing
docs.text: Open interactive CityPatternThing diagram

docs.title: Specializations of CityPatternThing
docs.text: Class Description City City Administrative Area Jurisdictional Area (TransportInfrastructurePattern) Transport Infrastructure Thing

docs.title: Formalization for CityPatternThing
docs.text: Property Constraint subClassOf CityThing

docs.title: CityResident
docs.text:
NOTE: Different cities have different definitions of who is that city's Resident, the City Resident Pattern contains the core properties required by each. For example, the city of Toronto's definition of a city resident includes the concept of owning property or owning or operating a business in the city. For Beijing, nationality is a unique aspect. Central to all the definitions is the concept of residing.

Open interactive CityResident diagram

docs.title: Formalization for CityResident
docs.text: Property Constraint hasResidence all Residence operates all EntityOperation owns all EntityOwnership residentOf all JurisdictionalArea subClassOf CityResidentThing subClassOf Person

docs.title: City Resident Pattern
docs.text:
This ontology specifies the city-level concepts for the city resident pattern of the city data model. As different cities have different definitions of who is that city's Resident, the City Resident Pattern must contain the properties required by each. Central to all of the definitions is the concept of residing. Variously referred to as a home or domicile in which the resident spends significant amounts of time. They may own it, rent it or just stay in it. Legally, “reside means to dwell permanently or continuously. It expresses an idea that a person keeps or returns to a particular dwelling place as his fixed, settled, or legal abode. The meaning of reside implies a continuous arrangement” ; reside has both a temporal and spatial dimension. The city of Toronto's definition of a city resident includes the concept of owning property or owning or operating a business in the city. For Beijing, nationality is a unique aspect.

This pattern imports the following patterns:

  • Building Pattern
  • Organization Pattern

This pattern consists of the following classes:

  • City Resident
  • City Resident Thing
  • Controlled Entity
  • Entity Operation
  • Entity Ownership
  • Home Type
  • Residence
  • Residential Relationship

The formal definition of this pattern is available in OWL Syntax.

docs.text: Open interactive CityResidentThing diagram

docs.title: City Service Pattern
docs.text:
This ontology specifies the city-level concepts for the city service pattern of the city data model. Cities provide a variety of services to residents and businesses, including health and social services. The city service ontology, is based on the Canadian Government Reference Model (CGRM). See Wiseman, R. (2015). Canadian Governments Reference Models. In Service Systems Science (pp. 109-128). Springer, Tokyo.

This pattern imports the following patterns:

  • Person Pattern

This pattern consists of the following classes:

  • Catchment Area Type
  • City Service Thing
  • Impact Direction
  • Importance
  • Input
  • Outcome
  • Output
  • Program
  • Service
  • Stakeholder

The formal definition of this pattern is available in OWL Syntax.

docs.title: Code Pattern
docs.text:
This ontology specifies the city-level concepts for the code pattern of the city data model. The Code Pattern provides a structure to address the challenge of value enumeration with a general approach. In city data there are many classes of things that are intended to be instantiated using a set list of values (e.g., classification systems), however these values may change based on application or context. The Code Pattern introduces a generic set of classes and properties that can be used to extend such classes to define various classification systems in an integrated way. Instead of enumerating value sets for classes, values can be defined with an associated Code that specifies additional metadata about the value and its origins.

This pattern imports the following patterns:

  • Core
  • Organization Structure Pattern

This pattern consists of the following classes:

  • Code
  • Code Thing

The formal definition of this pattern is available in OWL Syntax.

docs.title: Contract Pattern
docs.text:
This ontology specifies the city-level concepts for the contract pattern of the city data model. A contract is a legal document that specifies some agreement(s) between two or more parties. The aim of the contract pattern is not to formalize the semantics of all possible involved legal concepts, but rather to enable to representation of the general structure and contents of a particular contract. The Contract Ontology adopts the definition of Contract specified in the Financial Business Ontology (FIBO) [8] specified at: https://spec.edmcouncil.org/fibo/ontology/FND/Agreements/Contracts/ with a key modification that a Contract is defined as a type of Document and is distinct from an Agreement (not a subclass, as specified in FIBO).

This pattern imports the following patterns:

  • Agreement Pattern
  • Organization Pattern

This pattern consists of the following classes:

  • Condition Precedent
  • Contract
  • Contract Thing
  • Contractual Commitment
  • Contractual Definition
  • Contractual Element
  • Non Binding Term
  • Representation
  • Warranty

The formal definition of this pattern is available in OWL Syntax.

docs.title: Household Pattern
docs.text:
This ontology specifies the city-level concepts for the household pattern of the city data model. The Household pattern captures basic information about households within the city. In particular it represents the different types and structures of households.

This pattern imports the following patterns:

  • City Resident Pattern

This pattern consists of the following classes:

  • Household
  • Household Thing

The formal definition of this pattern is available in OWL Syntax.

docs.title: Infrastructure Pattern
docs.text:
This ontology specifies the city-level concepts for the infrastructure pattern of the city data model. The Infrastructure pattern defines the concepts needed to capture various types of city infrastructure, such as buildings and roads. The Infrastructure pattern reuses the Spatial Location pattern (from ISO 5087-1) in order to capture the location of these infrastructure elements.

This pattern imports the following patterns:

  • Contact Pattern

This pattern consists of the following classes:

  • Infrastructure Element
  • Infrastructure Thing

The formal definition of this pattern is available in OWL Syntax.

docs.title: InfrastructureThing
docs.text: Open interactive InfrastructureThing diagram

docs.title: Specializations of InfrastructureThing
docs.text: Class Description Bridge Bridge Segment Building Building Unit Facility Infrastructure Element Rail Line Rail Link Rail Segment Road Road Link Road Network Type Road Segment Travelled Way Travelled Way Link Travelled Way Segment Tunnel Tunnel Segment

docs.title: Formalization for InfrastructureThing
docs.text: Property Constraint subClassOf CityThing

docs.title: LandUseClassification
docs.text:
NOTE: Land Use Classifications provide a means of describing the use in a standard way. Various classification systems are used to identify types of land use, such as LBCS, CLUMP, and AAFC.

Open interactive LandUseClassification diagram

docs.title: Formalization for LandUseClassification
docs.text: Property Constraint hasCode all Code subClassOf LandUseThing

docs.title: Used by classes
docs.text: Class Property Land Area landUse

docs.title: Land Use Pattern
docs.text:
This ontology specifies the city-level concepts for the land use pattern of the city data model. The Land Use Pattern captures concepts related to land use and cover over time. Land Use Classifications provide a means of describing the land cover/use in a standard way. Various classification systems are used to identify types of land use. Currently, we include LBCS, CLUMP, and AAFC. The ontology reuses and extends the Land Based Classification Standards (LBCS) Ontology presented by (Montenegro, Gomes, Urbano, and Duarte, 2011) for this purpose.

This pattern imports the following patterns:

  • Code Pattern

This pattern consists of the following classes:

  • Land Area
  • Land Use Classification
  • Land Use Thing

The formal definition of this pattern is available in OWL Syntax.

docs.title: Organization Pattern
docs.text:
This ontology specifies the city-level concepts for the organization pattern of the city data model. The Organization pattern is an extension of the Organization Structure pattern defined in ISO/IEC 5087-1 that introduces city-specific concepts related to Organizations such as Students and Employees.

This pattern imports the following patterns:

  • City Service Pattern
  • Recurring Event Pattern

This pattern consists of the following classes:

  • Business Establishment
  • City Org Thing
  • Compensation
  • Employment
  • Employment Status
  • For Profit Organization
  • Goal
  • Government Organization
  • Industry Type
  • Jurisdictional Area (OrganizationPattern)
  • Non Profit Organization
  • Occupation
  • Operation
  • Organization
  • Organization Agent
  • Role
  • Salary
  • Wage

The formal definition of this pattern is available in OWL Syntax.

docs.title: Person Pattern
docs.text:
This ontology specifies the city-level concepts for the person pattern of the city data model.

This pattern imports the following patterns:

  • Contact Pattern

This pattern consists of the following classes:

  • Citizenship
  • Education
  • Gender
  • ID Type
  • Name
  • Person
  • Person Id
  • Person Name
  • Person Thing
  • Sex
  • Skill

The formal definition of this pattern is available in OWL Syntax.

docs.title: Program
docs.text:
EXAMPLE: A "poverty reduction program” can be made up of a set of Services such as mobiles services that provides food and clothing to those that live on the street, and a training service that provides basic skills for those living on the street. A Program has a set of Stakeholders that may contribute or benefit.

Open interactive Program diagram

docs.text: Property Constraint cdm1:hasDescription max 1 owl:Thing cdm1:hasName max 1 owl:Thing hasBeneficialStakeholder all Stakeholder hasContributingStakeholder all Stakeholder hasInput all Input hasOutcome all Outcome hasOutput all Output hasService all Service subClassOf CityServiceThing subClassOf cdm1:Activity

docs.title: Transport Infrastructure Pattern
docs.text:
This ontology specifies the city-level concepts for the transport infrastructure pattern of the city data model. The Transportation Infrastructure pattern defines the concepts that are relevant in describing the physical transportation infrastructure and their characteristics. This includes the concepts of a Road, Bridge, and Tunnel. The Infrastructure Pattern is reused here, as these transportation structures are all defined as types of (subclasses) Infrastructure Elements.

This pattern imports the following patterns:

  • Infrastructure Pattern

This pattern consists of the following classes:

  • Bridge
  • Bridge Segment
  • Rail Line
  • Rail Link
  • Rail Segment
  • Road
  • Road Link
  • Road Network Type
  • Road Segment
  • Transport Infrastructure Thing
  • Travelled Way
  • Travelled Way Link
  • Travelled Way Segment
  • Tunnel
  • Tunnel Segment

The formal definition of this pattern is available in OWL Syntax.

docs.title: TransportInfrastructureThing
docs.text: Open interactive TransportInfrastructureThing diagram

docs.title: Formalization for TransportInfrastructureThing
docs.text: Property Constraint subClassOf CityPatternThing
